The witches cackle.
Targeting sensors are locked on the cloaked ship, Mister Marr.
Well done, Tallis. Fire!
Whoosh, kaBOOM! Series of smaller explosions.
Nooooo!
Oh, my God. The cloaked ship has been destroyed and we're in the path of incoming debris.
Shields!
Too late, Commander.
Alarms.
Hull breach in section three.
Marr, you idiot. He has no idea what he's just done. Get us back to the surface of Talderun.
Don't worry, sir. We're heading there anyway.
The planet's being torn apart. We have to find the relic and re-establish the equilibrium.
Aiee, it is over! The relic is gone, destroyed!
How can you know that?
I see it. A woman knows when love is gone. I see it! All will be consumed by the energy converter.
Then you do understand the technology.
I am not ignorant, alien.
We may only have a few minutes. There has to be a way to shut it down!

Impossible. It's designed for perpetual activity. It will attempt to convert all available power around it. If it is not fed a constant supply from the lodestone, it will convert first this planet, then the entire system!
And then Shara's reality will collapse, triggering a cascade across the Time Space Continuum.
Now you understand the importance of our role here. No one should ever have come here. We kept them at bay for aeons.
I never doubted that. I just don't agree with your methods.
The price of our failure is a high one. Are you still sure we were so wrong?
If we've lost the lodestone, then we have to replace it with another. You've studied the texts. Show them to me.
On the altar. The energy converter. Here.
Read the inscriptions. What do they tell us about establishing an equilibrium? Can we trade something, or someone, off against the energy converter?
Spaceship lands and powers down. Footsteps on planet surface.
Greetings, Tallis, Marr. Glad you could join us. I don't suppose you know Lieutenant Cochrane, the only survivor of the SS Tempest, of your failed mission.
No, we've not met. Tallis.
Mister Marr.
Blaster shot. Cochrane screams.
Cochrane!
(in pain) Sorry, Commander. Guess our hand was useless after all.
Damn it, Cochrane.
How touching.
You are a butcher.
And you're a greedy little man, Harlon. Greedy for money and life.
Not that different, then, are we?
I'd have expected you to shoot me by now, but you haven't. Idiot. I don't see any guns. Why not, I wonder? Oh, don't tell me, Commander. You let those women take them.
Well, I hope you're happy. You've destroyed the entire fleet for want of information. This information.
Give me the data cube.
The roof's caving in. The witches are fleeing, leaving us. Peri, we should follow their example and go.
I can't just leave Rom.
They can't do him any more harm now. He's paid his penance. He's free.
I'm sorry, Rom.
Peri! We have to leave him!
(crying) Goodbye, Rom.
Peri, come on!
Coming.
Falling rubble.
Ah, I see. I was right. According to the inscriptions, we can restore normality if only we can find a suitable replacement for Shara's lodestone, the skeleton.
The time is lost. All my hopes. I shall never join Shara now.
What do you mean, join Shara? Stand up! Tell me.
The Other was chosen across Space and Time. Chosen to be Shara's familiar in this world, to restore him to life and lead me to shoulder his burden in the other world.
You could give Shara back his life so that you could become an eternal like him? Swap with him? Tell me!
It is too late. The disequilibrium
If only the Tardis was closer, I could stabilise this disturbance.
Falling stone, Jal Dor Kal screams.
Jal Dor Kall!
Tell me what this has all been for, or I'll throw this into the lava. Tell me!
The Alpha Project.
But what's it for?
No, no, please don't throw the data cube. I'll tell you. I'll tell you. The Alpha Project is a duplicate of the temple of Shara.
An energy converter? Oh, I have to hear this. Why do you want it?
I wanted the secret of Shara. The High Priestess and I
You? You and that witch? She destroyed our fleet. She and her witches sliced and diced my crews, and you knew it? You approved?

Shara has lived for an eternity. Eternal life, Harlon. Think of it. Total power. It's in your hand at this very moment. I must have that data cube. I need the missing element. What was the device that drew the power into the system? You studied the sensor logs. Tell me!
Do you know, the funny thing is, you could have had the secret. I'm no scientist, but I reckon the relic was at the centre of all this, the magnet that drew the power here, and you just destroyed it.
You betrayed me! Sold them on to a rival bidder.
Not me. You're just being paranoid. I got there too late. I was about to retrieve the relic from that cloaked ship when you blew it out of the stars!
I don't understand. Tallis?
Well, how was I to know.
Oh, don't blame your flunky, Marr. You've done this, Mister Chairman. You've begun the destruction of this planet, and now we're all going to die here.
Jal Dor Kal didn't trust me.

You moron! She was using you. Can't you see it? She was going to create more gods and use it on herself. Oh. Oh, don't tell me. You thought you'd become a god. I reckon we're all better off without any gods, and you are definitely not getting this.
No! Not the cube!
Splosh.
Oh, without that I'm ruined. I've invested everything in the Alpha Project. I'll see to it your family suffers for this. Tallis!
Mister Chairman.
Do we still have his children under guard.
Oh, no, sir.
But I ordered
I know you did, sir, but I thought I'd wait and see how this venture turned out. You see, Wendle Marr, you're no god. You're not even much of a man. Goodbye, Mister Chairman.
Blaster shot. Marr screams. Splosh.
You always were too hot to handle.
What now? You kill me, I suppose.

If you want to see your family again, Harlon, I suggest we use the ex-Chairman's ship to get off this planet. I'm not interested in being seen to wield power. I let others do that. I'm content to be more subtle.
Are you suggesting an alliance?
Perhaps.
I'm not allowing the Alpha Project to continue. No one should have that kind of power.
Whatever. Why don't we discuss it on the way home, Mister Chairman?
Jal Dor Kal, I'll get you out. You have to tell me about the Other.
Doctor! You're alive! I knew it.
Rumours of my death and all that, Peri.
We have to get out of here, Doctor.
Antranak yowls.
That sounds like a consensus to me. However, it's not that simple. Jal Dor Kal, can you hear me?
(coughs) The Other should climb the steps of the altar and stand on the point of reason. The spirit will release my lord.
But who is the Other? Tell me, please.
It is no use. It is over for all of us. (dies)
No.
Doctor, we have to leave now.
We can't, Peri. This is only the beginning, don't you see? Chaos will spiral out from Nekromanteia, the cosmos will unravel. I have to try and stop this. I can't leave.
Where are you going, Doctor?
You heard what she said. Someone has to stand on the emitter array at the top of the energy converter so that they can become the new lodestone, the new conduit for energy.
You can't go up there. The converter's falling apart.
I have no choice.
Doctor, no!
Get back, both of you. You shouldn't come up here.
You might be killed!
If I don't succeed, we'll all be dead in any case. Besides, I've been dead already today. There's nothing to fear.
We cannot climb higher. This tower is ready to give way.
I have to be near the emitters!
Is that the emitter? What now?
I'm not sure. Shara! Can you hear me? I'm here! I'm offering myself as the new lodestone.
Look, above us. A great sphere spinning.
That's his reality touching ours.
Now, Doctor. leap into the sphere.
Goodbye, Peri. Take care of her, Erimem.
Doctor, no! You can't leave me!
Wait, Doctor. Perhaps this is my duty, my destiny. There had to be a reason for our meeting, for you taking me aboard your Tardis.
You don't know that.
Perhaps I am the one that the priestess spoke of. This Other. I did feel drawn here. It is me, I know it.
It must be now, Doctor, or all is lost.
Thank you, Doctor. I could never have been a Pharaoh, I know that now. Please, it is my role in the universe to do this thing.
Your cat doesn't agree, Erimem, and neither do I
Antranak, go back! Get down from there!
Cat yowls.
Antranak, no!
Overlapping voices, backwards whoosh, falling rubble. Quiet.
Doctor!
(coughs) Peri, Erimem.
You're safe.
Were we victorious, Doctor?
You know, I think we were.
Antranak, he's back.
Thank you, Doctor. You brought me enlightenment. Life and death is everything. I see that now, now that death calls me.
Antranak? Is that really you?
Shara, goodbye.
My experiment is over. Goodbye, my friend.
Tardis door opens and closes.
Hello, old girl. Hmm, that doesn't sound very healthy.
So, what else is new?
Hmm. Pay no attention.
I shall miss Antranak.
Yes, I'm er sorry about that, but it did seem to be his choice.
Perhaps it was that alien from Egypt in his head.
Perhaps.
Cats are noble creatures. I prefer to think it was Antranak the cat who made the decision. I am sad he has gone.
Next time we visit Earth, the Doctor'll find you a new Antranak, won't you?
Oh, must I?
+ ERIMEM: Yes!
The Tardis dematerialises.
<Back to the 5th Doctor episodes

HARLON: Oh, don't blame your flunky, Marr. You've done this, Mister Chairman. You've begun the destruction of this planet, and now we're all going to die here.
MARR: Jal Dor Kal didn't trust me.
HARLON: You moron! She was using you. Can't you see it? She was going to create more gods and use it on herself. Oh. Oh, don't tell me. You thought you'd become a god. I reckon we're all better off without any gods, and you are definitely not getting this.
MARR: No! Not the cube!
MARR: Oh, without that I'm ruined. I've invested everything in the Alpha Project. I'll see to it your family suffers for this. Tallis!
TALLIS: Mister Chairman.
MARR: Do we still have his children under guard.
TALLIS: Oh, no, sir.
MARR: But I ordered
TALLIS: I know you did, sir, but I thought I'd wait and see how this venture turned out. You see, Wendle Marr, you're no god. You're not even much of a man. Goodbye, Mister Chairman.
TALLIS: You always were too hot to handle.
HARLON: What now? You kill me, I suppose.
TALLIS: If you want to see your family again, Harlon, I suggest we use the ex-Chairman's ship to get off this planet. I'm not interested in being seen to wield power. I let others do that. I'm content to be more subtle.
HARLON: Are you suggesting an alliance?
TALLIS: Perhaps.
HARLON: I'm not allowing the Alpha Project to continue. No one should have that kind of power.
TALLIS: Whatever. Why don't we discuss it on the way home, Mister Chairman?
DOCTOR: Jal Dor Kal, I'll get you out. You have to tell me about the Other.
PERI: Doctor! You're alive! I knew it.
DOCTOR: Rumours of my death and all that, Peri.
ERIMEM: We have to get out of here, Doctor.
DOCTOR: That sounds like a consensus to me. However, it's not that simple. Jal Dor Kal, can you hear me?
JAL DOR KAL: (coughs) The Other should climb the steps of the altar and stand on the point of reason. The spirit will release my lord.
DOCTOR: But who is the Other? Tell me, please.
JAL DOR KAL: It is no use. It is over for all of us. (dies)
DOCTOR: No.
PERI: Doctor, we have to leave now.
DOCTOR: We can't, Peri. This is only the beginning, don't you see? Chaos will spiral out from Nekromanteia, the cosmos will unravel. I have to try and stop this. I can't leave.
ERIMEM: Where are you going, Doctor?
DOCTOR: You heard what she said. Someone has to stand on the emitter array at the top of the energy converter so that they can become the new lodestone, the new conduit for energy.
PERI: You can't go up there. The converter's falling apart.
DOCTOR: I have no choice.
ERIMEM: Doctor, no!
DOCTOR: Get back, both of you. You shouldn't come up here.
PERI: You might be killed!
DOCTOR: If I don't succeed, we'll all be dead in any case. Besides, I've been dead already today. There's nothing to fear.
ERIMEM: We cannot climb higher. This tower is ready to give way.
DOCTOR: I have to be near the emitters!
PERI: Is that the emitter? What now?
DOCTOR: I'm not sure. Shara! Can you hear me? I'm here! I'm offering myself as the new lodestone.
ERIMEM: Look, above us. A great sphere spinning.
DOCTOR: That's his reality touching ours.
SHARA: Now, Doctor. leap into the sphere.
DOCTOR: Goodbye, Peri. Take care of her, Erimem.
PERI: Doctor, no! You can't leave me!
ERIMEM: Wait, Doctor. Perhaps this is my duty, my destiny. There had to be a reason for our meeting, for you taking me aboard your Tardis.
DOCTOR: You don't know that.
ERIMEM: Perhaps I am the one that the priestess spoke of. This Other. I did feel drawn here. It is me, I know it.
SHARA: It must be now, Doctor, or all is lost.
ERIMEM: Thank you, Doctor. I could never have been a Pharaoh, I know that now. Please, it is my role in the universe to do this thing.
DOCTOR: Your cat doesn't agree, Erimem, and neither do I
ERIMEM: Antranak, go back! Get down from there!
ERIMEM: Antranak, no!
PERI: Doctor!
DOCTOR: (coughs) Peri, Erimem.
PERI: You're safe.
ERIMEM: Were we victorious, Doctor?
DOCTOR: You know, I think we were.
ERIMEM: Antranak, he's back.
SHARA: Thank you, Doctor. You brought me enlightenment. Life and death is everything. I see that now, now that death calls me.
ERIMEM: Antranak? Is that really you?
DOCTOR: Shara, goodbye.
SHARA: My experiment is over. Goodbye, my friend.
DOCTOR: Hello, old girl. Hmm, that doesn't sound very healthy.
PERI: So, what else is new?
DOCTOR: Hmm. Pay no attention.
ERIMEM: I shall miss Antranak.
DOCTOR: Yes, I'm er sorry about that, but it did seem to be his choice.
PERI: Perhaps it was that alien from Egypt in his head.
DOCTOR: Perhaps.
ERIMEM: Cats are noble creatures. I prefer to think it was Antranak the cat who made the decision. I am sad he has gone.
PERI: Next time we visit Earth, the Doctor'll find you a new Antranak, won't you?
DOCTOR: Oh, must I?
PERI: + ERIMEM: Yes!
